ygData.subject: Re: Numbers of species
ygData.msgSnippet: I think the numbers you guys are discussing are reasonable.  I think a good rule of thumb for me has been to aim for an average size of 15.  My version of

Subject: Re: Numbers of species
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=y861U7a4M_tcn5QALglWfp4u6CxM6-BMj5B0eVh5qy4OB6RnRmNR
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

I think the numbers you guys are discussing are reasonable.  I think 
a good rule of thumb for me has been to aim for an average size of 
15.  My version of NEAT, and perhaps others, uses a truncation 
selection that knocks the bottom n% of the population out of 
contention for reproduction (specified by the 
parameter "survival_thresh," which sats what percentage should 
survive).  That is something to consider.  If you are selecting very 
strictly within species, then you want bigger species.  So I know 
that if survival_thresh is 0.3, then a species of 15 will have about 
5 individuals of high quality mating with each other.

The other issue is dynamic vs. static compatibility thresholding.  
Because I do not like to spend a lot of time tuning parameters 
unnecessarily, I greatly prefer the dynamic method.  I realize there 
are actually a lot of interesting arguments for going either way.  
Another way to articulate this reasoning for going dynamic is that 
if you are going to choose a parameter, it is much more intuitive to 
choose the species size target rather than a meaningless threshold 
value.  

There is a further reason that I like the dynamic method, which is 
that long-term population dynamics are very hard to predict, even 
with a lot of tuning.  Just because you have found a threshold that 
consistently leads to 10 species arising in 100 generations, does 
not mean there will still be 10 after 1000.  Chaotic dynamics and 
sudden disasterous of serendipitous events can alter the population 
distribution radically at some unforseen point in the future.  I 
like to know that no matter what, the population will settle around 
my target # of species.

This is actually a complicated issue with a lot of pros and cons, 
both philosophical and practical, either way.  Unfortunately. I do 
not know of any extensive experimentation that gives empirical 
support to either method, so it's really an open question.  My 
personal biases may not necessarily pan out to be the best.

I'm actually not completely sure what the word "clamp" means. Does 
it mean you are doing dynamic thresholding in the style of my NEAT 
system, or does it mean you literally stop speciation from 
progressing after some number already exist?  (I guess Derek or you 
may be able to answer this question) My dynamic thresholding is 
constantly moving towards a target number by moving the 
compatibility threshold, which doesn't seem like a "clamp" exactly, 
so I think clamping may be a third option.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Matt Simmerson" <m.simmerson@b...> 
wrote:
> Thanks for that Derek.  Personally, I try to have the average 
specie
> size to be about 10, which allows for sorting and the mating of the
> top n%, either by tuning the threshold manually or choosing the
> required number of species for dynamic threshold manipulation.
> 
> I haven't clamped my species, to be honest, never even thought of 
it
> as an option.
> 
> I have thought about having an average specie size of around 30 as
> this is supposed to be the min size of a cow herd, for example, to
> have enough genetic material to produce healty offspring.  Not so 
sure
>  it matters so much here if brother and sister mate though.
> 
> Also, I seem to remember 30 being the smallest statistically
> significant size for a sample, so maybe we should always aim for 
that
> number of species.
> 
> Ken, any thoughts/opinions as to specie number clamping or specie 
size
> etc.
> 
> Cheers
> 
> Matt
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> > Hi Matt,
> > 
> > I think to a certain extent it's dependent on your population 
size. 
> > Larger populations are more tolerant of more species.
> > 
> > I think most of the current NEAT implementations clamp the 
number of
> > species...something like 5-8 (please correct me if I'm wrong on 
this).
> >  Obviously if you only have 1 species, you're not exploiting its
> > advantages...likewise if you have a population of 100 and you 
have 100
> > species (everyone is in their own species), you're not getting 
any
> > crossover.
> > 
> > ANJI doesn't clamp the number of species, and so we end up 
tuning the
> > threshold manually.  We usually end up with somewhere between 20-
30
> > species in a typical run.
> > 
> > Theoretically, I like to think of species as camps moving out 
into the
> > search space and exploring.  They're clusters of similar 
solutions in
> > the fitness landscape.  You don't want too many and you don't 
want too
> > few.  And you want a certain amount of turnover or dynamism, 
because
> > you want to encourage more exploration, and probably have some 
search
> > spaces abandoned in favor of more promising ones.
> > 
> > Others may have some insights into why they clamped the species 
size.
> > 
> > The short answer, though not very helpful, is somewhere between 
1 and
> > your population size. :)
> > 
> > Derek
> > 
> > On 9/7/05, Matt Simmerson <m.simmerson@b...> wrote:
> > > Hi
> > > 
> > > Just wondering if anyone has any view as to the optimum(ish) 
number of
> > > species.  My implementation will cope with both a fixed and 
dynamic
> > > compatability threshold so I can control the number of species 
to a
> > > certain degree.
> > > 
> > > I find that with a fixed CT, the number of species decline 
eventually
> > > to just a few, after intially having many (tens/hundreds).
> > > 
> > > Thoughts, opinoins etc very much welcomed.
> > > 
> > > Cheers
> > > 
> > > Matt
